items.reasoning: Both are Pauline greeting formulas with nearly identical structure: 'grace and peace to you from God our Father and the Lord Jesus Christ.' This is literary_parallel (shared epistolary convention) + theological_principle (grace/peace theology).
Identical Pauline greeting formula structure across epistles. Literary_parallel captures the formulaic nature better than generic allusion.
Both discuss God's election and sanctification. Primary theological_principle (election doctrine) with literary_parallel (similar Pauline vocabulary: 'God chose you').
Both teach divine election and sanctification. Theological_principle (soteriology) is sufficient; no strong literary connection beyond shared doctrine.
Both affirm God's eternal plan before creation. Theological_principle (divine sovereignty) sufficient; different contexts and vocabulary.
Both discuss adoption (huiothesia). Theological_principle (adoption doctrine) primary; literary_parallel (Paul's distinctive adoption vocabulary across epistles) secondary.
Both teach predestination and conformity to Christ. Theological_principle (soteriology/predestination) is sufficient.
Both discuss grace and redemption. Theological_principle (justification) with literary_parallel (Paul's 'grace' vocabulary).
Eph-Col parallels show extensive literary similarity. Both discuss being in 'the beloved/Son he loves' with similar vocabulary. Literary_parallel primary due to Eph-Col connection.

Nearly identical phrasing: 'redemption through his blood, the forgiveness of sins' (Eph) / 'redemption, the forgiveness of sins' (Col). Strong literary_parallel (Eph-Col connection) + theological_principle (redemption).
Both discuss redemption through blood. Theological_principle (atonement) with shared_metaphor (blood imagery).
Both discuss God's mystery revealed. Theological_principle (mystery revealed) with literary_parallel (Paul's 'mystery' vocabulary pattern).
Eph 3:3 explicitly elaborates the mystery mentioned in 1:9. Perfect elaboration with theological_principle (mystery of Christ).
Eph 3:9 further elaborates the mystery from 1:9. Clear elaboration + theological_principle.
Both discuss 'fullness of time' but in different contexts (cosmic reconciliation vs. kingdom arrival). Theological_principle (eschatology) sufficient; thematic_echo too weak.
Both use 'fullness of time' (pleroma) language. Theological_principle (divine timing) with literary_parallel (Paul's distinctive pleroma usage).
Both affirm Christ's cosmic supremacy over 'all things in heaven and earth.' Christological_parallel (Christ's universal lordship) with literary_parallel (Eph-Col connection).
Both describe Christ reconciling all things. Christological_parallel (Christ's cosmic reconciliation) + literary_parallel (Eph-Col shared theology).
Both discuss God's purpose and predestination. Theological_principle (divine sovereignty) with literary_parallel (Paul's 'purpose' vocabulary).
Eph 3:11 elaborates God's eternal purpose from 1:11. Clear elaboration + theological_principle.
Eph 1:12 repeats the 'for the praise of his glory' refrain from 1:6 in the christological hymn structure. Elaboration sufficient (threefold refrain pattern).
Both are part of the threefold 'praise of his glory' refrain in the christological hymn (vv. 6, 12, 14). Literary_parallel captures the structured pattern.
Both discuss Holy Spirit as seal/deposit. Theological_principle (pneumatology) with shared_metaphor (seal imagery).
Eph 4:30 references back to the sealing by the Spirit mentioned in 1:13. Elaboration (ethical implications) + theological_principle (Spirit's sealing).
Both discuss 'word of truth, the gospel' with nearly identical phrasing. Literary_parallel (Eph-Col) + theological_principle.
Both discuss Spirit as 'firstfruits' or 'deposit' guaranteeing redemption. Theological_principle (eschatological salvation) with literary_parallel (Paul's deposit/firstfruits vocabulary).
Both use 'deposit' (arrabon) for the Spirit. Theological_principle + literary_parallel (Paul's distinctive arrabon vocabulary).
Identical 'deposit' (arrabon) language for the Spirit. Strong theological_principle + literary_parallel.
Both are Pauline prayer reports with similar structure and vocabulary ('have not stopped praying for you'). Literary_parallel (Eph-Col) primary.
Both discuss Spirit's revelation of God's wisdom. Theological_principle (revelation) with literary_parallel (Paul's 'spirit of wisdom' vocabulary).
Eph 1:18 elaborates the 'hope' and 'inheritance' mentioned in 1:11. Elaboration + theological_principle.
Eph 4:4 references the 'one hope' from 1:18. Elaboration + theological_principle (unity).
Eph 3:7 references the power mentioned in 1:19. Elaboration within Ephesians' power theology.
Eph 3:16 prays for the power mentioned in 1:19. Clear elaboration.
Eph 6:10 applies the power from 1:19 ethically ('be strong in the Lord's mighty power'). Elaboration.
Both discuss God's power for transformation. Theological_principle (divine power) with christological_parallel (Christ's power).
Both affirm Christ's exaltation above all powers/names. Christological_parallel (Christ's supremacy) primary.
Both list cosmic powers under Christ's authority with similar vocabulary ('thrones, dominions, rulers, authorities'). Christological_parallel + literary_parallel (Eph-Col).
Both affirm Christ as head over all powers. Christological_parallel + literary_parallel (Eph-Col).
Eph 4:15 applies the 'head' imagery from 1:22 to church growth. Elaboration (ethical application) + theological_principle (ecclesiology).
Both declare Christ as 'head' of the body/church with similar vocabulary. Christological_parallel + literary_parallel (Eph-Col shared body metaphor).
Both use 'head' and body growth metaphor. Shared_metaphor (body imagery) + christological_parallel (Christ as head).
Eph 3:19 elaborates the 'fullness' from 1:23. Elaboration + theological_principle.
Eph 4:10 elaborates Christ filling all things from 1:23. Elaboration + christological_parallel.
Both discuss 'fullness' (pleroma) dwelling in Christ. Christological_parallel (Christ's fullness) + literary_parallel (Eph-Col pleroma theology).
Both affirm Christ as 'all in all.' Christological_parallel + literary_parallel (Eph-Col).
Eph 2:5 repeats and elaborates 'dead in transgressions' from 2:1. Perfect elaboration + theological_principle.
Nearly identical language: 'dead in your transgressions.' Literary_parallel (Eph-Col) + theological_principle (spiritual death/life).
Both discuss sinful nature/flesh. Theological_principle (hamartiology) with literary_parallel (Paul's flesh vocabulary).
Both discuss 'wrath' on disobedience with similar vocabulary. Literary_parallel (Eph-Col) + theological_principle.
Both discuss salvation while dead/helpless. Theological_principle (grace in salvation) sufficient.
Both discuss being raised to new life. Theological_principle (resurrection with Christ) + literary_parallel (Paul's raised-with-Christ vocabulary).
Eph 2:5 repeats and elaborates 2:1 ('dead in transgressions... made alive'). Clear elaboration.
Nearly identical phrasing: 'made you alive with Christ.' Literary_parallel (Eph-Col) + theological_principle.
Both discuss God's kindness appearing. Theological_principle (divine grace) + literary_parallel (Pauline 'kindness' vocabulary).
Both discuss God's gift, but different contexts (salvation vs. living water). Theological_principle sufficient; thematic_echo too weak.
Both teach justification apart from works. Theological_principle (sola fide) + literary_parallel (Paul's faith/works contrast vocabulary).
Both affirm salvation 'not by works.' Theological_principle + literary_parallel (Pauline formula).
Both affirm salvation 'not by works.' Theological_principle + literary_parallel (Pauline formula).
Both discuss circumcision/uncircumcision in similar contexts. Literary_parallel (Eph-Col) + theological_principle (Gentile inclusion).
Both discuss Israel's covenants. Theological_principle (covenant theology) sufficient.
Both contrast having/not having hope using similar Pauline vocabulary. Literary_parallel captures the shared phrasing.
Both discuss peace/reconciliation through Christ's blood. Literary_parallel (Eph-Col) + theological_principle (atonement).
Both discuss unity in one body. Theological_principle (ecclesial unity) sufficient.
Both discuss 'new creation' in Christ. Theological_principle (new creation) + literary_parallel (Paul's 'new' vocabulary).
Both teach unity transcending Jew/Gentile division. Theological_principle (unity in Christ) + literary_parallel (Paul's unity formula).
Both discuss reconciliation and peace. Literary_parallel (Eph-Col) + theological_principle.
Both discuss abolishing/canceling the law's requirements with similar vocabulary. Strong literary_parallel (Eph-Col) + theological_principle (law's end).
Both discuss reconciliation through the cross. Literary_parallel (Eph-Col) + theological_principle (atonement).
Paul alludes to Zechariah's peace proclamation to near and far. Allusion + prophecy_fulfillment (messianic peace realized).
Eph 3:12 elaborates the 'access to the Father' from 2:18. Elaboration + theological_principle.
Eph 4:4 references 'one Spirit' from 2:18's Trinitarian access. Elaboration + theological_principle.
Both use building/foundation metaphor for church, but different foundations (Peter vs. apostles/prophets). Shared_metaphor + theological_principle.
Both use foundation metaphor (though different foundations: Christ vs. apostles/prophets). Shared_metaphor + theological_principle.
Both use building/stone metaphor for church. Shared_metaphor (building imagery) + theological_principle (ecclesiology).
Both mention twelve apostles as foundation, but different contexts (church vs. New Jerusalem). Shared_metaphor sufficient.
Both use temple metaphor for church/believers. Shared_metaphor (temple imagery) + theological_principle (ecclesiology).
Eph 4:15-16 elaborates the growth/building theme from 2:21. Elaboration + shared_metaphor (building/body imagery).

Eph 3:1 begins with 'For this reason I, Paul...' and 4:1 resumes with 'As a prisoner for the Lord, then, I urge you...' after the prayer digression. Narrative_continuation captures the resumed thought.
Both reference Paul's imprisonment with similar vocabulary. Literary_parallel (Pauline self-reference pattern) sufficient.
Both discuss Paul's stewardship/commission with nearly identical language. Literary_parallel (Eph-Col) + theological_principle.
Eph 3:3 explicitly elaborates the mystery from 1:9-10. Perfect elaboration.
Both discuss the mystery now revealed with similar vocabulary. Literary_parallel (Eph-Col mystery language) + theological_principle.
Eph 3:5 discusses revelation to apostles/prophets, elaborating the 'Spirit of wisdom and revelation' from 1:17. Elaboration.
Eph 3:6 explicitly states the mystery: Gentiles are fellow heirs, elaborating 2:14-16's reconciliation theme. Perfect elaboration.
Both discuss God's power working through Paul's ministry with similar vocabulary. Literary_parallel (Pauline ministry vocabulary).
Both describe Paul as servant of the gospel. Literary_parallel (Eph-Col) + theological_principle.
Both discuss Paul's commission as servant with similar vocabulary. Literary_parallel (Eph-Col) + theological_principle.
Both express Paul's self-assessment as 'least' with similar vocabulary. Literary_parallel (Pauline humility formula).
Both discuss the mystery hidden for ages now revealed. Theological_principle (mystery revealed) + literary_parallel (Paul's mystery vocabulary).
Both discuss God's wisdom. Theological_principle (divine wisdom) sufficient; different contexts.
Both discuss God's wisdom/mystery. Theological_principle + literary_parallel (Paul's wisdom vocabulary).
Eph 3:10 elaborates that the 'rulers and authorities' from 1:21 learn God's wisdom through the church. Elaboration.
Eph 6:12 references the 'rulers and authorities' from 3:10. Elaboration (different perspective: learning wisdom vs. opposing believers).
Both discuss angels/powers learning about salvation. Theological_principle (revelation to spiritual beings) sufficient.
Eph 3:11 elaborates God's 'eternal purpose' from 1:11. Elaboration + theological_principle.
Eph 3:12 elaborates the 'access to the Father' from 2:18. Elaboration + theological_principle.
Both encourage bold access to God with confidence. Theological_principle + parallel_instruction (similar exhortation).
Both reference bowing/kneeling, but different contexts (prayer vs. universal worship). Shared_metaphor (kneeling imagery) sufficient.
Both discuss God's power/strength. Theological_principle + literary_parallel (Paul's strength vocabulary).
Both discuss God's riches providing. Theological_principle + literary_parallel (Paul's 'riches' vocabulary).
Both pray for God's power/strength with similar vocabulary. Literary_parallel (Eph-Col prayer language) + theological_principle.
Both discuss Christ/God dwelling in believers, but different contexts. Theological_principle (divine indwelling) sufficient.
Both use 'rooted' metaphor for spiritual stability. Literary_parallel (Eph-Col) + shared_metaphor (root imagery).
Both discuss Christ's fullness, but different contexts. Theological_principle sufficient.
Both discuss fullness in Christ. Christological_parallel (Christ's fullness) + literary_parallel (Eph-Col pleroma theology).
Both discuss believers' fullness in Christ. Christological_parallel + literary_parallel (Eph-Col pleroma theology).
Eph 3:20 doxology references the power from 1:19-20. Elaboration (doxological application).
Both discuss God's power working in believers. Literary_parallel (Eph-Col) + theological_principle.
Eph 4:1 resumes the interrupted thought from 3:1 ('For this reason...' / 'Therefore I urge you...'). Clear narrative_continuation.
Both reference Paul's imprisonment with similar vocabulary. Literary_parallel (Pauline self-reference).
Both reference imprisonment 'in/for the Lord.' Literary_parallel (Pauline imprisonment references).
Both give nearly identical virtue lists: humility, gentleness, patience, bearing with one another. Parallel_instruction (household code pattern) + literary_parallel (Eph-Col).
Both instruct about unity and peace. Parallel_instruction + literary_parallel (Eph-Col).
Both use 'one body' metaphor. Theological_principle (unity) + shared_metaphor (body imagery).
Both teach 'one body, one Spirit' with similar vocabulary. Theological_principle (unity) + shared_metaphor (body/Spirit imagery).
Eph 4:4 elaborates the 'one body' from 2:16. Elaboration + theological_principle.
Eph 4:4 references 'one Spirit' from 2:18. Elaboration + theological_principle.
Both discuss grace/gifts measured to each person. Theological_principle + literary_parallel (Paul's grace-gift vocabulary).
Both discuss Spirit's gifts given to each person. Theological_principle + literary_parallel (Paul's gift vocabulary).
Both discuss Christ's descent/ascent, but different contexts (incarnation vs. post-resurrection). Christological_parallel sufficient.
Both may reference descent to the dead (if that's the interpretation). Theological_principle + allusion (1 Pet alludes to Eph's descent).
Eph 4:10 elaborates Christ 'filling all things' from 1:23. Elaboration + christological_parallel.
Both list church offices/gifts. Theological_principle (church offices) + literary_parallel (Paul's office lists).
Both discuss body of Christ. Theological_principle + shared_metaphor (body imagery).
Eph 4:13 references 'fullness of Christ' from 1:23. Elaboration + theological_principle.
Both discuss maturity/perfection in Christ with similar vocabulary. Literary_parallel (Eph-Col) + theological_principle.
Both contrast childishness with maturity. Parallel_instruction + shared_metaphor (children imagery).
Eph 6:11 elaborates protection against 'schemes' from 4:14. Elaboration (armor of God as answer to deceit).
Eph 4:15 applies the 'head' imagery from 1:22 to church growth. Elaboration + shared_metaphor (body/head imagery).
Nearly identical language about body growth from the head with joints/ligaments. Strong literary_parallel (Eph-Col) + shared_metaphor.
Both discuss Gentile futility/darkened minds. Theological_principle (hamartiology) + literary_parallel (Paul's futility vocabulary).
Eph 4:17 references the former way of life from 2:2 ('as the Gentiles do... as you used to'). Elaboration (no longer walk that way) + contrast.
Both describe God giving people over to sin. Theological_principle (divine judgment) + literary_parallel (Paul's 'gave over' vocabulary).
Both command putting to death similar vices (sensuality, impurity, greed). Parallel_instruction + literary_parallel (Eph-Col).
Both use 'old self/man' metaphor. Theological_principle (sanctification) + shared_metaphor (clothing imagery).
Both command putting off/to death old self. Parallel_instruction + literary_parallel (Eph-Col).
Nearly identical commands to 'put off' old self with similar vocabulary. Strong parallel_instruction + literary_parallel (Eph-Col).
Both command putting off/getting rid of sin. Parallel_instruction + shared_metaphor (clothing imagery).
Both command renewal of mind. Parallel_instruction + literary_parallel (Paul's renewal vocabulary).
Both discuss new creation/self. Theological_principle + shared_metaphor (new/old imagery).
Nearly identical command to 'put on new self' with similar vocabulary. Strong parallel_instruction + literary_parallel (Eph-Col).
Paul may allude to Zechariah's command to speak truth. Allusion + parallel_instruction (similar ethical command).
Both command putting away lying. Parallel_instruction + literary_parallel (Eph-Col).
Both command working with hands. Parallel_instruction + literary_parallel (Paul's work ethic vocabulary).
Both address speech accountability, but different contexts. Theological_principle + parallel_instruction (speech ethics).
Both command edifying speech. Parallel_instruction + literary_parallel (Paul's edification vocabulary).
Both command putting away corrupt/filthy speech. Parallel_instruction + literary_parallel (Eph-Col).
Eph 4:30 references the Spirit's sealing from 1:13-14. Perfect elaboration (ethical implication).
Both command not grieving/quenching the Spirit. Parallel_instruction + literary_parallel (Paul's Spirit commands).
Nearly identical vice lists to put away (anger, rage, malice, slander). Strong parallel_instruction + literary_parallel (Eph-Col).
Both command putting away similar vices (malice, slander). Parallel_instruction sufficient.
Nearly identical commands: be kind, compassionate, forgiving. Strong parallel_instruction + literary_parallel (Eph-Col).
Both command imitating God/being perfect as Father is perfect. Parallel_instruction sufficient (similar ethical exhortation).
Both command loving as Christ loved. Parallel_instruction + theological_principle (Christlike love).
Both discuss Christ giving himself for us. Theological_principle (atonement) + literary_parallel (Paul's self-giving vocabulary).
Both discuss Christ's self-giving love. Theological_principle + literary_parallel (Paul's 'loved me and gave himself' formula).
Nearly identical commands about sexual immorality, impurity, greed. Strong parallel_instruction + literary_parallel (Eph-Col).
Eph 5:4 elaborates corrupt speech from 4:29 with specific examples. Elaboration.
Both command avoiding filthy/obscene speech. Parallel_instruction + literary_parallel (Eph-Col).
Both warn certain sinners won't inherit kingdom with similar vice lists. Theological_principle + literary_parallel (Paul's exclusion warnings).
Both identify greed as idolatry and warn against it. Parallel_instruction + literary_parallel (Eph-Col).
Both discuss God's wrath on disobedience. Theological_principle + literary_parallel (Paul's wrath vocabulary).
Both warn against deceptive words/arguments. Parallel_instruction + literary_parallel (Eph-Col).
Both warn against deception. Parallel_instruction + literary_parallel (Eph-Col).
Nearly identical warning about God's wrath on disobedience. Strong literary_parallel (Eph-Col) + theological_principle.
Both use light/darkness metaphor, but different contexts. Shared_metaphor + theological_principle.
Eph 5:8 contrasts current light with former darkness from 2:2. Elaboration + contrast (then/now).
Both command rejecting darkness/deeds. Parallel_instruction + shared_metaphor (light/darkness).
Both discuss light exposing deeds. Shared_metaphor (light/exposure) + theological_principle.
Possible liturgical citation or hymn fragment about awakening/rising. Allusion (unknown source) + shared_metaphor (sleep/wake).
Both command waking from sleep. Parallel_instruction + shared_metaphor (sleep/wake imagery).
Nearly identical command to 'make the most of every opportunity.' Strong parallel_instruction + literary_parallel (Eph-Col).
Both command understanding God's will. Parallel_instruction + literary_parallel (Paul's 'God's will' vocabulary).
Paul may allude to Proverbs' warning against drunkenness. Allusion + wisdom_principle (practical warning).
Paul may allude to Proverbs' warning against wine. Allusion + wisdom_principle.
Nearly identical commands about singing psalms/hymns/spiritual songs. Strong parallel_instruction + literary_parallel (Eph-Col).
Both command mutual submission/humility. Parallel_instruction sufficient.
Paul may allude to Genesis creation order, though not directly quoting. Allusion + theological_principle (order in creation).
Both discuss headship. Theological_principle (authority order) + shared_metaphor (head imagery).
Both discuss cleansing through word. Shared_metaphor (washing/cleansing) + theological_principle.
Both discuss sanctification through word/truth. Theological_principle + shared_metaphor.
Both discuss cleansing/washing. Theological_principle + shared_metaphor (washing imagery).
Eph 5:27 elaborates the holiness/blamelessness from 1:4. Elaboration + theological_principle.
Both describe presenting holy and blameless. Literary_parallel (Eph-Col) + theological_principle.
Both use body metaphor for church. Shared_metaphor + theological_principle.
Both discuss believers as members of Christ's body. Theological_principle + shared_metaphor.
Both use body/members metaphor. Shared_metaphor + theological_principle.
Paul quotes Genesis 2:24 ('For this reason a man will leave... and be united... one flesh'). Clear quotation + theological_principle (marriage theology).
Both quote Genesis 2:24 on marriage. Parallel_account (both quoting same OT text) appropriate.
Both instruct wives about submission. Parallel_instruction (household code pattern) sufficient.
Both instruct wives about submission. Parallel_instruction sufficient.
Nearly identical household code: children obey parents. Strong parallel_instruction + literary_parallel (Eph-Col household codes).
Paul quotes the fifth commandment ('Honor your father and mother'). Quotation + legal_parallel (Decalogue).
Paul quotes Deuteronomy's version of the fifth commandment. Quotation + legal_parallel.
Both reference the fifth commandment. Parallel_account (both citing same commandment).
Nearly identical household code for fathers. Strong parallel_instruction + literary_parallel (Eph-Col).
Nearly identical household code for slaves with extensive vocabulary overlap. Strong parallel_instruction + literary_parallel (Eph-Col).
Both instruct slaves. Parallel_instruction + literary_parallel (Pauline household codes).
Both promise reward from the Lord. Parallel_instruction + literary_parallel (Eph-Col).
Paul may allude to Job's principle of equality before God. Allusion + theological_principle.
Nearly identical household code for masters. Strong parallel_instruction + literary_parallel (Eph-Col).
Both command putting on armor/weapons of light. Parallel_instruction + shared_metaphor (armor imagery).
Both command putting on armor. Parallel_instruction + shared_metaphor (armor imagery).
Eph 6:12 elaborates the spiritual powers from 3:10 (different perspective: opposing vs. learning). Elaboration + theological_principle.
Both list armor pieces. Parallel_instruction + shared_metaphor (armor imagery).
Both discuss faith overcoming/extinguishing evil. Theological_principle + shared_metaphor (shield/victory imagery).
Both command taking helmet of salvation. Parallel_instruction + shared_metaphor (armor imagery).
Both use sword metaphor for God's word. Shared_metaphor (sword imagery) + theological_principle.
Both discuss Spirit-enabled prayer. Theological_principle + literary_parallel (Paul's prayer vocabulary).
Both command constant prayer. Parallel_instruction + literary_parallel (Paul's prayer commands).
Nearly identical commands about devoted prayer and alertness. Strong parallel_instruction + literary_parallel (Eph-Col).
Nearly identical prayer requests for bold proclamation of the mystery/gospel. Strong literary_parallel (Eph-Col) + parallel_instruction.
Both mention Tychicus being sent. Historical_reference (Paul's coworkers) sufficient.
Both mention sending coworkers. Historical_reference (Paul's mission plans) sufficient.
Nearly identical statements about sending Tychicus with nearly word-for-word correspondence. Strong literary_parallel (Eph-Col) + historical_reference.
Both use Pauline closing formula with peace. Literary_parallel (epistolary closing pattern) sufficient.
Both use Pauline peace benediction formula. Literary_parallel (epistolary closing) sufficient.
